children.name: when the opposite of what is expected happens
ironic
children.definition: sth that is ironic is funny, but in a sad or strange way, because it is the opposite of what you would expect: trớ trêu, nực cười
examples: ▪ ‘I’ve heard that Dan’s really upset about the divorce.’ ‘How ironic. He was always the one who was against them getting married in the first place.’
▪ It was an ironic situation, the two men in her life meeting like that.
it is ironic that : thật nực cười là
▪ It’s ironic that the most important people in the country often have so little understanding of how ordinary people live.
ironically[adv] một cách nực cười
▪ Life is full of ironies, some hilarious, some tragic.irony of
the irony is that : thật nực cười là
Ironically, the government ended up harming the very people it was trying to help.

children.name: irony[
examples: C or U] sth that is funny, but in asadorstrangeway, because it is the opposite of what you would expect:
The irony of the situation was obvious -- if I told the truth, nobody would believe me!
The irony is that some of the poorest countries have the richest natural resources.

children.name: sth that happens or exists because of sth else
result
children.definition: sth that happens because of sb’s actions or because of sth else that happened before: kết quả

children.name: a direct result
examples: The closure of the hospital is a direct result of Government reforms.

children.name: an indirect result
examples: Some job losses were the indirect result of cheap imports.

children.name: the end/final result
children.definition: the result at the end of a long process
examples: The end result will be well worth the effort.

children.name: the net result
children.definition: the final result
examples: The net result of fewer officers on the street was rising crime.

children.name: the immediate result
examples: Keep trying even if your first enquiry produces no immediate result.

children.name: the inevitable result
children.definition: a result that is impossible to avoid
examples: Weight loss is an inevitable result of the disease.

children.name: the desired result
examples: These severe measures did not always produce the desired results.

children.name: positive results
examples: The charity has seen positive results from health care and farming projects.

children.name: with disastrous results
examples: The parachute failed to open properly, with disastrous results.

children.name: achieve/obtain a result
examples: You can achieve the same result by simply clicking on the menu.

children.name: produce a result
examples: A different approach might produce some interesting results.

children.name: have a result
children.definition: cause something to happen
examples: The campaign did have some positive results.

children.name: result of
examples: Accidents are the inevitable result of driving too fast.

children.name: as a result (of sth)
examples: As a result of the pilots’ strike, all flights have had to be cancelled.

children.name: with the result that
examples: Sara wasn’t at school last week, with the result that she missed an important test.

children.name: effect
children.definition: when a person or situation is changed by sth that happens or sth that sb does: ảnh hưởng
examples: effect on
My parents’ divorce had a big effect on me.
The death of a parent can have very serious and long-lasting effects on a child.
effect of
The effects of the oil spill were devastating for wildlife
the harmful effects of radiation
have an effect/have no effect
All my efforts to persuade them were beginning to have an effect.

children.name: have an effect on something/somebody
examples: Eating junk food will eventually have an effect on your health.

children.name: have the effect of doing something
examples: The news had the effect of making everyone feel better.

children.name: produce an effectformal
examples: If we combine these sounds, they produce an effect that is almost jazzy.

children.name: feel an effect
children.definition: notice it
examples: Small companies will feel the effect of the recession first.

children.name: lessen/reduce an effect
children.definition: make an effect smaller or less severe
examples: The government must take action to reduce the effects of pollution.

children.name: cushion the effect of something
children.definition: make it less bad
examples: Lower mortgage rates will cushion the effect of rising house prices.

children.name: an effect lasts
children.definition: continues
examples: The effect of the drug lasts about six hours.

children.name: an effect wears off
children.definition: gradually stops
examples: The effect of the anaesthetic was beginning to wear off.

children.name: big/major
examples: The teachers’ strike had a big effect on many schools.

children.name: significant/substantial/marked
children.definition: quite big
examples: Global warming could have a significant effect on agriculture in many parts of the world.

children.name: profound/powerful
children.definition: very big, in a way that changes someone or something significantly
examples: My father’s death had a profound effect on me.

children.name: dramatic
children.definition: very big and sudden
examples: Taking the new drug had a dramatic effect on his health.

children.name: small
examples: The drugs have a relatively small effect on a lot of patients.

children.name: negligible/minimalformal
children.definition: very small
examples: The advertising campaign had a negligible effect on demand.

children.name: immediate
children.definition: quick and sudden
examples: The announcement had an immediate effect on stock prices.

children.name: good
examples: Inflation can sometimes have some good effects on the economy.

children.name: positive/beneficial
children.definition: good, or helping someone or something in some way
examples: The incident had a very positive effect on his career.

children.name: bad
examples: Working too hard was beginning to have a bad effect on my health.

children.name: negative/detrimental
children.definition: bad or harmful
examples: the negative effects of low rainfall

children.name: harmful/damaging
children.definition: causing harm or damage to something or someone
examples: the harmful effects of drinking too much alcohol|Some of the effects can be quite damaging.

children.name: visible/noticeable
children.definition: an effect that you can clearly see
examples: He drank five beers, but they did not seem to have any visible effect on him.

children.name: the adverse effectsformal
children.definition: the bad effects
examples: No one told them about the adverse effects of smoking marijuana.

children.name: the long-term/short-term effect
children.definition: having an effect for a long or short time
examples: Many boxers suffer with the long-term effects of punches to the head.

children.name: a knock-on effect
children.definition: an effect that is caused by something that has happened before
examples: The strike could have a knock-on effect at other airports.

children.name: a cumulative effect
children.definition: the effect of many things happening one after the other
examples: The cumulative effect of these policies will be to push up inflation.

children.name: the desired effect
children.definition: the effect you want
examples: His team talk had the desired effect because the team went on to win the game.

children.name: the full effect
children.definition: the whole effect
examples: We won’t know the full effect of the tax changes until the end of the financial year.

children.name: a calming/soothing effect
children.definition: one that makes you feel less angry, excited, or nervous
examples: His words seemed to have a calming effect on the crowd.

children.name: consequence
children.definition: sth that happens, which are usually bad as a result of a particular action or set of conditions: hậu quả

children.name: be a consequence of something
examples: Low energy may be a consequence of sleeping badly.

children.name: have consequences
examples: Taking financial risks can have serious consequences.

children.name: accept/take the consequences
children.definition: understand and deal with them
examples: I’m prepared to accept the consequences of my decision.

children.name: face/suffer the consequences
children.definition: accept the bad results of something you have done
examples: He broke the law, and he will have to face the consequences.

children.name: consequences follow
children.definition: happen
examples: Once the decision has been made, consequences follow.

children.name: consider the consequences
children.definition: think what might happen as a result of something
examples: She jumped into the river without considering the consequences.

children.name: escape the consequences
children.definition: avoid them
examples: I knew I’d made a mistake and that I couldn’t escape the consequences.

children.name: the possible/likely consequences
examples: What are the likely consequences of these changes?

children.name: an inevitable consequence
children.definition: that you cannot avoid
examples: Loss of mobility is not an inevitable consequence of old age.

children.name: serious consequences
children.definition: bad and important
examples: Too much fishing in these seas has had serious consequences.

children.name: disastrous/dire consequences
children.definition: very bad and damaging
examples: If temperatures continue to rise, it could have disastrous consequences for agriculture.

children.name: an important consequence
examples: This discovery was an important consequence of his research.

children.name: social/political/economic consequences
examples: The rise in food prices has had enormous economic and political consequences.

children.name: a direct consequence of something
children.definition: a consequence directly caused by something
examples: The spread of information has been a direct consequence of the Internet.

children.name: a natural/logical consequence
children.definition: that naturally/logically follows something
examples: Obviously disappointment is a natural consequence of defeat.

children.name: a negative consequence
children.definition: a bad or unpleasant result
examples: the negative consequences of drinking too much alcohol

children.name: an adverse/unfortunate consequence
children.definition: that affects your life, a situation etc badly
examples: Divorce often has unfortunate consequences for children.

children.name: tragic consequences
children.definition: very sad, usually involving death
examples: Someone dropped a burning cigarette, with tragic consequences.

children.name: far-reaching consequences
children.definition: important and affecting many things
examples: The new law is sure to have far-reaching consequences.

children.name: long-term consequences
children.definition: results that last a long time, or appear after a long time
examples: If you smoke it may have long-term consequences.

children.name: consequence of
examples: Many believe that poverty is a direct consequence of overpopulation.

children.name: consequence for
examples: Our findings have far-reaching consequences for researchers.

children.name: with ... consequences
examples: He ate some poisonous mushrooms, with fatal consequences.

children.name: damaging/dire/disastrous etc consequences
examples: Safety procedures had been ignored, with disastrous consequences.

children.name: implication
children.definition: a possible future effect or result of an action, event, decision etc,especially when it affect what you think or do or what happens in the future: ảnh hưởng

children.name: important/serious implications
examples: The results of the experiment could have important implications for scientists.

children.name: major implications
children.definition: very important or serious
examples: The lack of affordable housing has major implications for families living in rural areas.

children.name: profound implications
children.definition: extremely important or serious
examples: The transformation of Europe has profound implications for the defence industries.

children.name: far-reaching implications
children.definition: causing things to change in an important way
examples: The cuts in social security benefits had far-reaching implications for ethnic minorities.

children.name: the wider implications
children.definition: affecting more people or society in general
examples: What are the wider implications of this change in the law?

children.name: the full implications
children.definition: all the different effects
examples: The full implications of the decision will become clear over the next few weeks.

children.name: possible implications
examples: We discussed the possible implications of oil price rises.

children.name: practical implications
examples: Academic research often has practical implications.

children.name: financial implications
examples: Managers must be aware of the financial implications of their decisions.

children.name: political implications
examples: The court’s decision could have far-reaching political implications.

children.name: legal implications
examples: We have taken advice on the legal implications of our activities.

children.name: social implications
examples: She’s studying the social implications of different patterns of work.

children.name: have implications
examples: This is an environmental disaster which will have implications for more than one country.

children.name: consider the implications
examples: Have you considered the implications of your choice?

children.name: discuss the implications
examples: The paper discusses the implications of the agreement.

children.name: study/examine the implications
examples: He has studied the implications of recent technical innovations.

children.name: realize/grasp the implications
children.definition: understand what they are
examples: The government has been slow to grasp the implications of the current teacher shortage.

children.name: implication of
examples: What are the implications of these proposals?
The legal implications of the case are extremely significant.

children.name: implications for
examples: Any change in interest rates has important implications for most people’s financial situation.

children.name: outcome
children.definition: the final result of a meeting, discussion, war etc – used especially when no one knows what it will be until it actually happensSYN result: kết thúc, kết cục
examples: Whatever the outcome, I hope we remain friends.
The talks had a better outcome than we had originally hoped.

children.name: the final/ultimate outcome
examples: The final outcome of the investigation is still to be announced.|The ultimate outcome of this controversy remains in doubt.

children.name: a likely outcome
examples: What is the likely outcome of the election?

children.name: a possible outcome
examples: When you throw a die, there are six possible outcomes.

children.name: a successful outcome
examples: Hopes for a successful outcome to the war were fading.

children.name: a positive outcome
children.definition: a good result
examples: Everyone is hoping for a positive outcome to the talks.

children.name: a happy outcome
children.definition: a good result, especially one that makes everyone happy
examples: Adopting a child does not automatically result in a happy outcome.

children.name: a satisfactory outcome
examples: Our main aim is to achieve a satisfactory outcome for both parties.

children.name: the desired outcome
examples: The desired outcome of most services is a satisfied customer.

children.name: a favourable/unfavourable outcome
examples: Considerable progress has been made towards a favourable outcome.|Discontinuing treatment too early may result in an unfavourable outcome.

children.name: a learning outcome
children.definition: what someone is supposed to learn from something
examples: It is important to set teaching objectives and learning outcomes.

children.name: a policy outcome
children.definition: what happens when a particular policy is used
examples: A number of factors affect policy outcomes.

children.name: a treatment outcome
children.definition: what happens whan a particular medical treatment is used
examples: Funding is provided to collect and analyze data on treatment outcomes.

children.name: a health outcome
children.definition: how healthy someone is after using a particular treatment, system etc
examples: the assessment of health outcomes

children.name: have an outcome
examples: The meeting had a very satisfactory outcome.

children.name: affect/influence the outcome
examples: Did coverage in the media affect the outcome of the trial?

children.name: decide/determine the outcome
children.definition: be the thing that causes the final result
examples: This move untimately decided the outcome of the conflict.|At the leadership elections today, it is their votes that will determine the outcome.

children.name: predict the outcome
children.definition: say what the final result will be
examples: It is too early to predict the final outcome of the survey.

children.name: await the outcome
children.definition: wait for the final result
examples: Medical science must await the outcome of proper international debate.

children.name: outcome of
examples: It was impossible to predict the outcome of the election.
People who had heard the evidence at the trial were surprised at the outcome.
Register Outcomeis slightly formal and is used mostly in writing. In everyday English, people are more likely to talk aboutwhat happened:
It was impossible to predictwhat would happenin the election.

children.name: upshot
children.definition: the result of something, especially when it is a little unusual or unexpected: kết cục

children.name: upshot of
examples: ▪ What was the upshot of the trial?

children.name: the upshot is that
examples: ▪ The upshot of that experience was that I decided I didn’t want to study medicine after all.

children.name: end result
children.definition: the final situation that exists after a long time, process, or series of events: kết thúc
examples: ▪ It was impossible for many small businesses to survive, and the end result was the loss of many jobs.
Là bất khả thi để các doanh nghiêp nhỏ có thể tồn tại và kết quả là mất đi nhiều công việc
the end result is that
▪ If students constantly fail, the end result is that they switch off any interest in learning.
Nếu học sinh rớt triền miên thì kết quả là họ từ bỏ mọi hứng thú với việc học

children.name: net result
children.definition: /net effect the final situation that exists when you consider all the details and facts - use this when this situation is not good: kết cục, hậu quả cuối cùng
examples: The net result of global warming will be a rise in sea levels.

children.name: the net result/effect is that
examples: The new system is designed to spread payments over several months but the net effect is that people pay more in total.

children.name: aftereffect
children.definition: a bad effect that exists for a long time after the activity or event that caused it: di chứng
examples: ▪ The earthquake struck a week ago but the city is still feeling the aftereffect
aftereffect of
▪ A large number of working days are lost through the aftereffects of alcohol abuse.
psychological aftereffects
▪ The psychological aftereffects of a tragedy like the Zeebrugge disaster can stay with the survivors for years.

children.name: when one thing happens because of another
because of
children.definition: if something happens because of an earlier problem, event etc, it happens as a result of it: bởi vì
examples: ▪ Sampras seemed likely to miss the US Open because of a back injury.
Sampras dường như bỏ lỡ giải mở rộng Mỹ vì chấn thương lưng
▪ Because of problems with the fuel system, the launch has been put back a week
Bởi vì những vấn đề với hệ thống nhiên liệu,việc tung ra sản phẩm mới phải hõa lại một tuần.
▪ She was chosen for the Peace Prize because of her courageous fight for democracy.
Cô ấy được chọn trao giải hòa bình bởi sự đáu tranh can đảm cho đảng dân chủ

children.name: be the result of sth
children.definition: be a result of/resultfrom   to happen because of something else that happened or was done: kết quả của
examples: ▪ Our success is the result of a great deal of hard work.

children.name: Thanh công của chúng ta là kết quả của sự làm việc chăm chỉ
examples: ▪ The big population increase in the US was partly the result of immigration.

children.name: Sự gia tăng dân số lớn ở Mỹ một phần là kết quả của sự di cư
examples: ▪ It is thought that the train crash resulted from a fault on the line.

children.name: Tôi nghĩ rằng vu tai nạn tàu hỏa là kết qủa của lỗi trên đường ray
resulting
children.definition: /consequent happening or existing because of sth else that happened before: kết quả
examples: Burrows took the resulting penalty kick.
Without government support the factory would be forced to close, with the consequent loss of thousands of jobs.
Britain’s resulting debt burden was greater than that of the French.

children.name: as a result of sth
children.definition: as a result of  happening because of something else:

children.name: là kết quả của
examples: ▪ He died as a result of cold and exhaustion.

children.name: Anh ta chết à kết quả cua rcasi lạnh và kiệt sức
examples: ▪ Over 60 drugs have been removed from sale as a result of recent tests.

children.name: Hơn 60 loại thuốc đã bị thu hồi buôn bán như là kết quả của những bài kiểm tra gần đây
be the product of
children.definition: to be the result of actions, experiences or good or bad conditions:

children.name: kết quả
examples: ▪ The agreement was the product of 21 months of negotiations.

children.name: Sự đồng ý là kết quả của 21 tháng đàm phán
examples: ▪ Saturday’s goal was the product of some poor defending by the opposing team.

children.name: Bàn thắng hôm thứ bảy là kết quả của một vài sự phòng vệ kém bên đói thủ
come of
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive phrasal verb not in progressive or passive]
children.definition: if something comes of a situation or activity, it happens because of it:
examples: là kết quả của
▪ The company is interested in the merger: many positive things could come of it.
Công ty rất hứng thú với việc sáp nhập,nhiều yếu tố tích cực có thể là kết quả của viejc này
nothing came/has come etc of somethingnothing happened because of something: không có cái gì là kết quả của
▪ I’ve applied for that job, but so far nothing’s come of it.
Tôi đã xin việc đó những chẳng có gì là kết quả của nó
no good comes etc of somethingsomething does not have a good result:không có kết quả tốt
▪ My mother always said that no good would come of the relationship.
Mẹ tôi luôn bảo rằng chẳng có kết quả gì tốt trong mối quan hệ

children.name: stem from
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive phrasal verb not in progressive or passive]
children.definition: if something, especially a problem, stems from something else, it develops because of it and is directly connected with it: bắt nguồn từ

children.name: stem from from (doing) sth
examples: ▪ Many of my patients’ anxieties stem from experiences in their childhood.
▪ The dog’s aggression stemmed from being kept locked up all day.

children.name: stem from the fact that
examples: ▪ Part of the education problem stems from the fact that class sizes have increased dramatically in the last 5 years.

children.name: arise from
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive phrasal verb not in progressive or passive]
children.definition: if sth such as a problem or difficult situation arises from something, it starts to exist because of it: nảy sinh từ
examples: ▪ The argument arose from a misunderstanding.
▪ Lung cancer is just one of the many diseases that arise from smoking too many cigarettes.

children.name: arise from the fact that
examples: ▪ The difficulty arises from the fact that there has been insufficient time to train new staff.

children.name: come out of
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive phrasal verb not in progressive or passive]
children.definition: to happen or exist as a helpful or useful result of sb’s actions, decisions or discussions: kết quả của
examples: ▪ We’re waiting to see what comes out of the inquiry before we make a decision.

children.name: ▪ Much of what came out of the Rio Summit did not have an immediate effect
a series of events and results
chain reaction
children.definition: a series of events, each of which is the result of the one before, and which cannot be stopped: phản ứng dây chuyền
examples: ▪ When oil prices rise, prices of other goods all over the world rise in a chain reaction.

children.name: chain reaction of
examples: ▪ A chain reaction of events eventually led to the Prime Minister’s resignation.

children.name: start/set off a chain reaction
examples: ▪ The revolution set off a chain reaction of revolts in neighbouring states.

children.name: knock-on effect
children.definition: UK sth that happens as a result of sth that has happened before, and that you do not want to happen: ảnh hưởng dây chuyền

children.name: knock-on effect of
examples: ▪ The knock-on effect of the rise in electricity prices is likely to be higher prices generally.

children.name: knock-on effect on
examples: ▪ Any reduction in community care for the elderly will have a knock-on effect on hospitals.

children.name: domino effect
children.definition: a series of events or actions, each one of which is caused by the effects of the previous one - use this especially about a series of bad things that happen: hiệu ứng dây chuyền
examples: If schools were allowed to become more selective, there would be a domino effect.
have a domino effect (on sth)
Opponents of the scheme claimed that if the museum moved from Golden Gate Park it would have a domino effect on the other facilities

children.name: a result that happens in addition to the intended result
side effect
children.definition: an unexpected or unplanned result of a situation or event: tác dụng phụ
examples: These policy changes couldhavebeneficialside effectsfor the whole economy.
Transplanting genes from one plant to another may have unintended side effects for the environment and the food supply.

children.name: side effect of
examples: One of the side effects of chemotherapy is hair loss.

children.name: indirect result
children.definition: a result that is indirectly caused by sth you do or that happens: kết quả gián tiếp

children.name: indirect result of
examples: The job losses were an indirect result of lower cost imports.
The increase in greenhouse gases is the direct result of pollution, and the indirect result of a reduction in the atmosphere’s ability to absorb them.

children.name: by-product
children.definition: an unexpected result of an event or sth you do, which happens in addition to the result you intended: kết quả phụ, tác dụng phụ, “phó phẩm”

children.name: by-product of
examples: ▪ One of the by-products of the peace treaty was the growth of trade between the two nations.
▪ Another by-product of space exploration is a growing awareness of this planet’s fragile environment.

children.name: corollary
children.definition: sth that is certain to happen in addition to the result you intend, so that you expect it but do not usually want it: kết qủa tất yếu, hệ quả

children.name: corollary of
examples: ▪ Huge increases in unemployment were the corollary of the government’s economic policy.

children.name: a logical/natural/necessary etc corollary (of something)
examples: ▪ A rapid increase in population would be a natural corollary of any such changes in the birth control program.

children.name: the corollary of this is that
examples: ▪ The government has promised tax cuts, but the corollary of this is that there will be a reduction in public services.

children.name: spin-off
children.definition: an unexpected but useful result of sth that you do, that happens in addition to the result that was intended: lợi ích phụ

children.name: spin-off for
examples: ▪ One of the main spin-offs for countries that host the Olympic Games is increased business for hotels, restaurants, and theatres.

children.name: have a spin-off
examples: ▪ Research into lasers has had important spin-offs for eye-surgery.

children.name: ramifications
children.definition: all the results of sth you do, which affect people in ways that were not intended and which you do not always expect when you first make the decision to do it:
examples: an agreement which was tohavesignificantramificationsfor British politics
ramification of
the practical ramifications of taking on a new job
The ramifications of the decision whether to build a new airport or not are enormous.
ramifications for
The course that people choose to do at university can have ramifications for the rest of their lives.
legal/political/economic etc ramifications
the environmental ramifications of the road-building program
Whatever the judges decide, the legal ramifications of the case will be with us for many years to come.
wider ramificationsmore complicated results kết quả phức tap
The introduction of national testing in schools had wider ramifications than people realized.

children.name: repercussions
children.definition: the additional and usually bad results of sth that happens, which continue to affect people for a long time afterwards in a way that was not intended or expected: ảnh hưởng, hậu quả

children.name: repercussion for
examples: The collapse of the companyhad repercussionsfor the whole industry.

children.name: repercussions of
examples: ▪ The psychological repercussions of the accident might affect her for the rest of her life.

children.name: have repercussions (on sth)
examples: The transport strike had all sorts of repercussions on other industries.
There wereserious repercussionson his career.

children.name: important/profound/serious etc repercussions
examples: ▪ A scandal like this could have serious repercussions on his political career.

children.name: economic/legal/political etc repercussions
examples: ▪ Even the possibility of a war in the Middle East has important political repercussions.

children.name: result
children.definition: nounTEST

children.name: impact
children.definition: noun

children.name: a powerful effect that something, especially something new, has on a situation or person
examples: _The anti-smoking campaign hadhad/madequite an impactonyoung people.
_The new proposals were intended tosoftenthe impact of the reformed tax system.

children.name: in
children.definition: prepositionRESULT

children.name: used when referring to something that is done as a result of something else
examples: _I'd like to do something for you inreturn/exchangefor everything you've done for me.
_The changes are inresponseto demand from our customers.
_He refused to say anything inreplyto the journalists' questions.

children.name: the fruit of sth
children.definition: the fruit/fruits ofsth

children.name: the pleasant or successful result of work or actions
examples: _This book is the fruit of 15 years' research.
_It's been hard work, but now the busines is running smoothly you can sit back and enjoy the fruitsof your labours.
